channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Little sign of peace after Trump Congo deal
item.description: Peace in eastern Congo remains elusive, despite a U.S.-brokered deal that President Trump calls historic.
item.content:encoded: Peace in eastern Congo remains elusive, despite a U.S.-brokered deal that President Trump calls historic.
item.dc:creator: Emmet Livingstone

item.title: What the H1B visa application fee hike could mean for the U.S. economy
item.description: An economist explains the impact the H-1B visa program has had on the U.S. economy and native-born workers. And what the new hundred thousand dollar fee could mean for the future of the program.
item.content:encoded: An economist explains the impact the H-1B visa program has had on the U.S. economy and native-born workers. And what the new hundred thousand dollar fee could mean for the future of the program.
item.dc:creator: Wailin Wong

item.title: Protests grow in Italy against Israel's offensive in Gaza
item.description: Protests calling for an end to Israel's offensive against Hamas brought hundreds thousands of people onto the streets in Italy, according to the labor union which helped organize them.
item.content:encoded: Protests calling for an end to Israel's offensive against Hamas brought hundreds thousands of people onto the streets in Italy, according to the labor union which helped organize them.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Debt, protests and right vs. left: A look at the political turmoil in France
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron struggles to govern as France faces protests, political deadlock, and a rising far right.
item.content:encoded: French President Emmanuel Macron struggles to govern as France faces protests, political deadlock, and a rising far right.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: Sean Combs sentenced to over four years in prison for prostitution-related charges
item.description: Combs had been convicted in July on two counts of transportation for prostitution. During his sentencing hearing he spoke at length for the first time in the trial, addressing the judge at length.
item.content:encoded:
Combs had been convicted in July on two counts of transportation for prostitution. During his sentencing hearing he spoke at length for the first time in the trial, addressing the judge at length.

(Image credit: Jane Rosenberg)
item.dc:creator: Isabella Gomez Sarmiento

item.title: A federal worker explains why she's not afraid of Trump's layoff threat
item.description: Some federal workers closely following President Trump's threats of mass layoffs and funding cuts in the shutdown say it's nothing new. He's been doing those same things since January.
item.content:encoded: Some federal workers closely following President Trump's threats of mass layoffs and funding cuts in the shutdown say it's nothing new. He's been doing those same things since January.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu

item.title: This week in science: Fly migration, a surprise in the Amazon and fish noises
item.description: Hosts of NPR's science podcast discuss new findings about long-distance fly migration, an unexpected impact of emissions in the Amazon, and fish noises.
item.content:encoded: Hosts of NPR's science podcast discuss new findings about long-distance fly migration, an unexpected impact of emissions in the Amazon, and fish noises.
item.dc:creator: Berly McCoy

item.title: For the first time, the Church of England names a woman as its top leader
item.description: For the first time, the Church of England has named a woman as its top leader. Sarah Mullally is the new Archbishop of Canterbury, leading 85 million Anglicans around the world.
item.content:encoded: For the first time, the Church of England has named a woman as its top leader. Sarah Mullally is the new Archbishop of Canterbury, leading 85 million Anglicans around the world.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Hamas agrees to release Israeli hostages, Trump tells Israel to stop bombing Gaza
item.description: The Palestinian militant group said it would release all the hostages after President Trump set a deadline of Sunday evening to sign up to his plan
item.content:encoded: The Palestinian militant group said it would release all the hostages after President Trump set a deadline of Sunday evening to sign up to his plan
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy

item.title: Daniel Day-Lewis is back. His son is just getting started
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with actor Daniel Day-Lewis and director Ronan Day-Lewis — father and son — about their new movie, Anemone.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with actor Daniel Day-Lewis and director Ronan Day-Lewis — father and son — about their new movie, Anemone.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly
